title: European Investment Bank annual report 2012: REPORT on the European Investment Bank (EIB) – Annual Report 2012
background: In 2012, the European Investment Bank (EIB) expanded operations under EU priorities amid economic stagnation, public budget constraints, and high youth unemployment. A EUR 10 billion capital increase aimed to enhance lending capacity, while concerns persisted over low SME financing and program country investments. The Parliament will discuss EIB’s strategic alignment with EU growth objectives, risk management, and operational transparency.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the EIB's capital increase and its €180 billion investment potential for SMEs and infrastructure, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to economic recovery through the Europe 2020 strategy.  
EPP applauds the Youth Employment Initiative and SME financing targets as critical tools to address unemployment, effectively advancing EPP's priority of job creation across all member states.  
EPP proposes enhancing transparency in crisis-country lending allocations by requiring quarterly reports on Program Country disbursements to ensure equitable distribution while maintaining portfolio quality.  
EPP endorses maintaining the EIB’s triple-A rating to preserve cost-effective market access, which directly supports EPP’s fiscal responsibility principles in long-term investment planning.  
EPP highlights the strategic importance of EIB-ERDB-World Bank cooperation on €30 billion commitments as exemplary alignment with EPP’s vision for strengthened EU external policy coherence.

EFD partially supports the Project Bond Initiative but demands reallocation of funds toward IT and R&D sectors to enhance EU competitiveness, as current energy/transport focus neglects innovation priorities.  
EFD requests revisions requiring EIB to disclose comprehensive geological studies and seismic risk analyses for infrastructure projects like Castor, citing transparency deficiencies in current implementation.  
EFD urges amendment of project selection criteria to prioritize measurable innovation potential, arguing the issue's infrastructure emphasis conflicts with smart growth objectives under Europe 2020.  
EFD highlights contradictions between the EIB’s risk-averse lending in crisis states and the urgent need for strategic investments in high-tech SMEs to address regional disparities.  
EFD calls for binding targets to phase out fossil fuel financing entirely, rejecting the issue’s incremental Emissions Performance Standard as misaligned with climate urgency.

GREEN_EFA fundamentally promotes the issue's climate action mandate, perfectly aligning with their commitment to phase out fossil fuel financing and accelerate renewable energy infrastructure under strengthened 2015 targets.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with demands for enhanced anti-fraud safeguards, particularly the prohibition of partnerships with entities operating in tax havens or engaging in corrupt practices as outlined in transparency reforms.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally promotes the call for quadrupled climate investment allocations, emphasizing the necessity to exceed current Emissions Performance Standards through binding renewable energy quotas by 2016.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly supports the Parliament's insistence on rigorous oversight of financial intermediaries, demanding immediate implementation of beneficiary ownership disclosures across all EIB-funded projects.  
GREEN_EFA fully aligns with youth employment prioritization, urging expansion of the €6 billion initiative to integrate green skills training matching renewable energy sector needs.

ALDE strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on expanding EIB lending for SMEs and climate initiatives, which aligns perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to fostering innovation and sustainable job creation.  
ALDE approves the €10 billion capital increase as a strategic tool to unlock investments but proposes enhancing transparency through real-time public disclosure of project selection criteria to strengthen accountability.  
ALDE applauds the introduction of Emissions Performance Standards and urges an accelerated phase-out plan for fossil fuel lending to align with EU decarbonization targets.  
ALDE emphasizes prioritizing renewable energy infrastructure in Eastern Partnership countries, leveraging the EIB’s role to advance energy security and EU external policy coherence.  
ALDE supports maintaining the triple-A rating while advocating for measured risk-taking in green technology projects to drive long-term competitiveness.

SD strongly upholds the EIB’s expanded lending capacity through the €10 billion capital increase, aligning with their commitment to economic recovery and job creation under the Europe 2020 strategy.  
SD applauds the focus on SME financing and youth employment initiatives, particularly endorsing the €19 billion target for SMEs and the €6 billion Youth Employment Initiative as critical drivers of inclusive growth.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of maintaining the EIB’s triple-A rating while urging enhanced risk-taking in crisis-hit Programme Countries to meet unmet lending targets and address regional disparities.  
SD proposes strengthening support for carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies alongside renewable energy investments, ensuring transitional energy security while adhering to climate goals.  
SD highlights the strategic importance of infrastructure projects like Nabucco for EU energy resilience and calls for accelerated implementation of the Connecting Europe Facility to bolster cross-border connectivity.

GUE/NGL supports the issue's climate commitments but advises amending the Emissions Performance Standard to explicitly exclude coal and nuclear energy investments while mandating community consultations for all large infrastructure projects.  
GUE/NGL endorses SME financing targets but urges reallocating 35% of the €60 billion lending expansion to crisis-hit Programme Countries through grants rather than market-rate loans.  
GUE/NGL expresses grave concern that EIB's risk-averse approach exacerbates regional inequalities, demanding binding quotas to direct 25% of annual investments to regions with youth unemployment exceeding 40%.  
GUE/NGL welcomes transparency reforms but insists on publishing beneficiary ownership data for all financial intermediary transactions within 15 days of disbursement.  
GUE/NGL stresses the need to decouple youth employment programs from austerity frameworks by establishing parallel EU-funded social housing and education initiatives.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of the European Investment Bank (EIB) in advancing EU priorities, including economic recovery, job creation, and climate action, while endorsing its 2012 activities, which financed 400 projects across 60 countries with €52 billion. It welcomed the €10 billion capital increase approved in 2012, enabling an additional €60 billion in EU lending (a 49% expansion) for 2013-2015, aiming to unlock €180 billion in investments, particularly for SMEs, infrastructure, innovation, and low-carbon initiatives under the Europe 2020 strategy. Concerns were highlighted over low EIB lending in crisis-hit Programme Countries (e.g., Greece, Ireland), where 2013 targets reached only €5 billion (8% of total EU lending), and the Bank’s risk-averse approach, urging enhanced risk-taking and transparency. The resolution emphasized boosting SME financing, citing 2013 targets of €19 billion for SMEs and mid-caps, alongside blended instruments like the Growth and Employment Facility and Project Bond Initiative (supported by €230 million from the EU budget), which approved nine infrastructure projects. Climate priorities were stressed, including the EIB’s new Emissions Performance Standard for fossil fuels and demands for a phase-out plan for non-renewable energy lending. Youth employment programs, such as the €6 billion Youth Employment Initiative, were noted, alongside calls for improved governance, compliance with anti-tax evasion standards, and cooperation with institutions like the EBRD and World Bank (jointly committing €30 billion for 2013-2014). The Parliament urged stricter oversight of financial intermediaries, enhanced transparency in project selection, and regular reporting on employment impacts and alignment with EU external policies, while safeguarding the EIB’s triple-A rating to maintain cost-effective market access.

title: ECA special report in the context of the 2009 Commission discharge: REPORT on the Court of Auditors' special reports in the context of the 2009 Commission discharge
background: The European Court of Auditors' 2009 reports on EU budget implementation identified financial management irregularities, prompting scrutiny under Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. The Parliament will discuss the Commission's budgetary accountability and adherence to sound financial practices for the 2009 fiscal year.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on Member States’ accountability in budget execution, aligning with their commitment to rigorous financial governance. They propose expanding mandatory national declarations to all Member States, leveraging successful models from Sweden and Denmark.  
EPP approves the call for suspending payments to countries with recurrent mismanagement, urging stricter enforcement to protect EU funds as outlined in the Court of Auditors’ systemic recommendations.  
EPP endorses the integration of gender budgeting principles into audit practices, emphasizing the need to operationalize feasibility study findings in policy design and evaluation frameworks.  
EPP emphasizes robust recovery mechanisms for misused funds, advocating accelerated procedures to address delays in reclaiming Traditional Own Resources lost through lax customs controls.  
EPP commends the issue’s alignment with systemic customs reforms, reinforcing their priority of transparent fiscal oversight through enhanced Court of Auditors’ follow-up audits.

EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on systemic audit improvements but advises withholding discharge approval until fraud investigations into EU agencies are conclusively resolved.  
EFD proposes amending discharge procedures to automatically suspend funding allocations to Member States with recurring irregularities, aligning with the issue’s risk management objectives.  
EFD highlights the EUR 6.3 billion in irregularities as evidence requiring stricter Commission enforcement powers, reinforcing the issue’s accountability framework.  
EFD cautions that budget increases for high-risk policy areas contradict financial governance principles unless paired with real-time fraud disclosure mechanisms to national auditors.  
EFD urges binding penalties for customs control failures quantified under Article 8 compliance reviews, operationalizing the issue’s focus on measurable losses.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on transparency and accountability in EU fund management, aligning perfectly with their commitment to rigorous financial oversight and democratic governance.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for integrating gender budgeting into audit practices, a critical step toward advancing equality as outlined in their policy priorities.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing parliamentary debate for major expenditures like the Museum of European History to ensure democratic scrutiny while maintaining support for cultural initiatives.  
GREEN_EFA endorses stricter controls on procurement procedures and conflict-of-interest safeguards, particularly for agencies like the EMA, to prevent financial mismanagement.  
GREEN_EFA strongly approves demands for Council budget transparency, reinforcing their longstanding advocacy for institutional accountability across all EU bodies.

ALDE strongly promotes the integration of gender equality principles across all budgetary stages, aligning with their commitment to equitable governance and Treaty adherence.  
ALDE applauds the Commission’s transparency in disclosing erroneous expenditures and setting criteria for payment suspensions, advancing fiscal accountability and systemic reform.  
ALDE urges accelerated adoption of national management declarations, emphasizing their necessity for the 2014 financial framework and reflecting ALDE’s Dutch-led advocacy for Member State accountability.  
ALDE approves the emphasis on quantifying financial losses from customs control gaps, reinforcing their stance on rigorous fiscal oversight and anti-fraud measures.  
ALDE proposes extending audit guidelines to explicitly incorporate gender-budgeting feasibility findings as a targeted enhancement to existing accountability frameworks.

SD strongly accepts the issue’s emphasis on political accountability for EU fund management, aligning with their demand that national management declarations bear ministerial signatures to ensure transparent oversight.  
SD approves the automatic fund-blocking mechanism for mismanaged resources, reinforcing Parliament’s systemic audit priorities as outlined in the issue’s governance framework.  
SD applauds the focus on taxpayer protection through efficient fraud recovery, directly advancing their manifesto commitment to shield citizens from financial losses due to misuse of EU funds.  
SD proposes enhancing recovery protocols by specifying that operational costs for reclaiming misused funds should not burden taxpayers, strengthening the issue’s financial governance objectives.  
SD endorses stricter ex-post evaluation guidelines to match their advocacy for rapid intervention in flawed fund management systems, as urged in the Court of Auditors’ follow-up audits.

ECR strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on systemic fund management improvements, aligning with their longstanding commitment to rigorous financial accountability.  
ECR approves the Court of Auditors' expanded audit role as critical for reinforcing Parliament’s oversight responsibilities under EU financial governance.  
ECR highlights enhancement opportunities to address recurring deficiencies in agency procurement and recruitment processes through strengthened ex-post evaluation guidelines.  
ECR applauds the focus on quantifying customs-related financial losses, directly advancing their priority of fiscal responsibility in budget execution.  
ECR proposes augmenting gender budgeting integration with explicit transparency metrics to ensure operational clarity without opposing the principle.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the implementation of the EU budget for 2009, emphasizing the need to integrate gender equality principles across all stages of the budgetary process, including preparation, execution, and auditing, as mandated by Article 8 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. It highlighted the importance of incorporating findings from a feasibility study on gender budgeting into audit practices and policy design. The resolution urged the Court of Auditors to conduct follow-up audits after the adoption of guidelines for ex-post evaluations and called on the Commission to quantify financial losses in Traditional Own Resources resulting from inadequate controls under simplified customs procedures in Member States. Additionally, it stressed the role of the Court of Auditors’ special reports in identifying systemic issues in fund management, reinforcing Parliament’s oversight responsibilities under the EU’s financial governance framework.

title: Annual Report 2012 on the protection of the EU's financial interests - Fight against fraud: REPORT on the Annual Report 2012 on the Protection of the EU’s Financial Interests – Fight against fraud
background: The EU faced persistent financial fraud risks, with 2012 reports indicating vulnerabilities in cohesion policy, agriculture, and VAT collection, alongside cross-border challenges. Institutional reforms like OLAF’s 2013 regulation and proposals for a European Public Prosecutor’s Office aimed to address gaps. The Parliament will discuss strengthening anti-fraud frameworks to safeguard EU budgetary integrity.

stances.stance:
EPP supports the issue's transparency objectives and urges the Commission to publish beneficiary lists of EU funds across all member states to deter fraudulent schemes.  
EPP advises enhancing member state accountability by mandating criminal investigations for fraud cases instead of relying solely on financial corrections.  
EPP recommends reforming OLAF's operational framework with standardized training and clear proportionality guidelines to improve investigation efficiency.  
EPP calls for strengthening the Supervisory Committee's mandate to ensure full access to case information, aligning with parliamentary oversight requirements.  
EPP highlights the need to revise rural development fund monitoring criteria to prevent exclusion of fraud suspicions from investigations.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s emphasis on transparency in public procurement, aligning perfectly with their commitment to combating corporate secrecy and ensuring accountable use of ecological transition funds.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the proposed European Public Prosecutor’s Office as a critical step toward addressing cross-border environmental fraud cases, effectively advancing their manifesto goal of institutionalizing eco-justice mechanisms.  

GREEN_EFA endorses the Hercule III program’s anti-fraud tools but proposes allocating 15% of its budget specifically to combat emerging climate-related financial crimes such as illegal carbon credit trading.  

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates uniform fraud definitions across Member States, urging immediate adoption to prevent exploitation of regulatory gaps in green subsidy allocations.  

GREEN_EFA approves the focus on tobacco smuggling’s financial and public health impacts while recommending extending monitoring frameworks to include illicit timber and wildlife trafficking networks.

ALDE supports the establishment of a European Public Prosecutor's Office as a cornerstone for safeguarding EU finances, in line with the issue's strategic goals.  
ALDE advises accelerating VAT system reforms through integration into the EU's revised own resources framework to mitigate systemic fraud risks.  
ALDE urges the Commission to foster dialogue with opposing member states to achieve a workable consensus on the European Public Prosecutor proposal.  
ALDE acknowledges the plateau in fraud detection efficacy and recommends reinforcing preventive measures and cross-border cooperation to enhance financial protection.  
ALDE endorses harmonized anti-fraud reporting standards but stresses the need for stricter enforcement to address inconsistent member state compliance.

SD strongly sanctions the issue’s focus on improving recovery mechanisms for defrauded EU funds, aligning perfectly with SD’s longstanding commitment to fiscal accountability. The €444 million recovered in 2012 demonstrates progress in safeguarding taxpayer interests.  
SD proposes amending reimbursement policies to retain recovered funds within the EU budget rather than returning them to member states, enhancing the Union’s financial capacity without opposing recovery principles.  
SD applauds the push for OLAF reforms and the European Public Prosecutor’s Office as measures that effectively advance SD’s priority of institutional transparency and cross-border anti-fraud cooperation.  
SD urges stricter enforcement of member state obligations to increase recovery rates, particularly in agriculture where 43% remains insufficient, framing this as an enhancement opportunity for budgetary justice.  
SD endorses uniform fraud definitions and procurement transparency requirements as critical steps to combat corruption, consistent with their manifesto pledges for EU governance reform.

ECR firmly condemns the issue's approach to combating tax fraud for failing to address excessive fiscal burdens that drive shadow economy participation.  
ECR rejects increased enforcement mechanisms without parallel tax reduction measures, citing survival-driven tax avoidance as incompatible with citizens' welfare priorities.  
The proposal contradicts ECR's core principle that lowering tax rates – not intensifying controls – is the primary solution to reducing fraud through voluntary compliance.  
ECR highlights the issue's critical oversight in linking the €193 billion VAT gap directly to high taxation rather than solely to collection inefficiencies.  
 While condemning fraud, ECR asserts no EU control system can override natural economic incentives created by "unreasonably high" tax demands on families and businesses.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s emphasis on combating tax evasion and corruption but urges binding mechanisms to ensure Member States implement anti-fraud frameworks rather than relying on non-enforceable declarations.  

GUE_NGL advises amending cohesion policy governance to prevent fund concentration in corporate interests, advocating redistributive clauses to prioritize public-sector projects and SME access.  

GUE_NGL highlights the stagnation in recovery rates since 2011, proposing mandatory biannual audits and penalties for states failing to reclaim over 50% of misused agricultural funds.  

GUE_NGL stresses the need to integrate privacy impact assessments into OLAF’s reformed investigative protocols, ensuring fraud probes do not enable mass surveillance of citizens.  

GUE_NGL calls for expanding the Hercule III program’s scope to fund grassroots oversight initiatives, enabling civil society to audit EU expenditures alongside centralized authorities.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the significant financial losses to the EU budget due to fraud, tax evasion, and corruption, estimating annual losses of EUR 1 trillion from tax fraud and evasion (costing each citizen EUR 2,000) and EUR 120 billion from corruption. It highlighted that 2012 saw 1,231 fraudulent irregularities totaling EUR 392 million, primarily in cohesion policy (EUR 279 million) and agriculture (EUR 143 million), while non-fraudulent irregularities surged to EUR 2.9 billion. The resolution stressed the need for enhanced cooperation between Member States and EU institutions, urging reforms to improve VAT collection (noting a 2011 VAT gap of EUR 193 billion) and combat smuggling, particularly in tobacco (costing EUR 11 billion annually). It welcomed initiatives like the European Public Prosecutor’s Office proposal, OLAF reforms to streamline investigations, and the Hercule III program (EUR 104 million budget) for anti-fraud tools. The Parliament called for stricter reporting standards, uniform fraud definitions, and better recovery mechanisms, criticizing Member States for delayed reporting, inconsistent data, and low recovery rates (e.g., 43% in agriculture). It emphasized transparency in public procurement, stronger anti-corruption measures, and the implementation of VAT directives (reverse charge mechanism) to safeguard financial interests, while urging timely follow-up on OLAF’s recommendations and improved governance to restore public trust.

title: Discharge 2010: EU general budget, Committee of the Regions - Decision on the discharge: REPORT on the discharge for implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2010, Section VII – Committee of the Regions
background: The 2010 EU budget implementation by the Committee of the Regions faced scrutiny following the European Court of Auditors' identification of procedural errors in staff recruitment and procurement, alongside internal audits and financial reporting. The Parliament will discuss compliance with budgetary regulations and accountability measures for administrative expenditure under its discharge oversight role.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on strict budget restraint and improved procurement controls, aligning with their fiscal responsibility priorities.  
EPP approves the enhanced HR transparency measures and online financial disclosures as critical steps toward institutional accountability.  
EPP proposes reinforcing audit timelines with binding deadlines for internal reports to match Parliament's oversight needs while maintaining full support for the discharge.  
EPP commends the CoR-EESC collaboration model as exemplary interinstitutional efficiency, directly advancing EPP's advocacy for streamlined EU governance.  
EPP endorses maintaining separate agencies for gender equality and fundamental rights despite merger suggestions, prioritizing policy precision over administrative savings.

EFD rejects the discharge approval as fundamentally incompatible with their demand for rigorous EU budget accountability, citing the Court of Auditors’ 3.7% error rate increase.  
EFD opposes the issue’s endorsement of CoR’s administrative spending, condemning the allocation of €200 million annually to “powerless bureaucratic structures” like CoR and EESC.  
EFD highlights contradictions in Parliament approving CoR’s 99.4% budget utilization while failing to address recurring procurement errors and revolving-door conflicts in agencies.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of fiscal waste, particularly the 7.7% error rate in cohesion/energy spending, which EFD deems irreconcilable with taxpayer interests.  
EFD asserts the issue’s praise for CoR’s “corrective measures” inadequately addresses systemic mismanagement, reinforcing their call to halt EU budget expansions.

GREEN_EFA strongly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on strict budget restraint and financing new activities through savings, aligning with their commitment to fiscal responsibility and efficient public fund allocation.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the call for enhanced HR transparency and online publication of members’ financial interests, recognizing these as critical steps toward accountability and trust in EU institutions.  
GREEN_EFA proposes extending the deadline for internal audits by 30 days to ensure thorough scrutiny while maintaining full support for the audit principle.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the issue’s demand for renewable energy usage data alongside EMAS certification, reinforcing their climate advocacy and push for sustainable institutional practices.  
GREEN_EFA urges the immediate publication of the Court of Auditors’ report on conflicts of interest at EMA and EFSA, framing this as an enhancement to the issue’s transparency goals.

ALDE strongly approves the issue's emphasis on strict budget restraint and financing new activities through savings, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to fiscal discipline and efficient resource allocation.  
ALDE approves the Committee of the Regions' corrective measures on procurement and recruitment errors, particularly the restricted-access tender system, as these effectively advance transparency in public contracting practices.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Member States' compliance with financial reporting obligations under Article 44 of the interinstitutional agreement to strengthen systemic accountability, while fully endorsing the issue's existing HR transparency requirements.  
ALDE applauds the CoR-EESC joint services model as exemplary interinstitutional cooperation, urging its expansion to other EU bodies to maximize administrative efficiency.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need for timely publication of renewable energy usage data tied to EMAS certification, aligning with their environmental governance priorities under Europe 2020.

SD strongly advocates the issue's emphasis on enhanced HR transparency and online publication of financial interests, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to institutional accountability.  
SD approves the CoR's corrective measures on procurement errors as effectively advancing budgetary integrity while proposing extending EMAS renewable energy reporting to biennial updates.  
SD commends the issue's recognition of CoR's subsidiarity role under Europe 2020, urging accelerated inclusion of impact reports in legislative files within 30 days rather than 60.  
SD endorses joint CoR-EESC service collaborations as model efficiency practices, suggesting replicating this framework across other EU advisory bodies.  
SD highlights the 99.4% budget utilization rate as demonstrating fiscal responsibility, while recommending future discharge reports explicitly quantify savings from austerity measures.

ECR rejects the discharge approval for the Committee of the Regions’ 2010 budget due to unresolved systemic deficiencies in procurement and staff recruitment, firmly opposeing with ECR’s demand for error-free financial governance.  
ECR opposes the issue’s endorsement of the CoR’s corrective measures, highlighting the Court of Auditors’ identification of recurring errors as evidence of inadequate accountability, inconsistent with ECR’s principle of zero tolerance for mismanagement.  
ECR condemns the 0.4% administrative error rate as unacceptably high for taxpayer-funded operations, a stance directly opposing the issue’s implicit acceptance of this figure.  
ECR disputes the issue’s praise for inter-institutional collaboration to achieve savings, arguing that shared services have not prevented structural fund error rate increases, failing to address ECR’s call for a full-time budgetary control commissioner.  
ECR challenges the issue’s omission of the European Parliament’s own budgetary accountability flaws, such as unvetted member expenses, which contradict ECR’s demand for uniform transparency across all EU institutions.

resolution: The European Parliament raised key observations and decisions regarding the Committee of the Regions’ (CoR) 2010 budget implementation, noting the Court of Auditors identified errors in staff recruitment and procurement for interpreting services but acknowledged corrective measures, including improved recruitment procedures, enhanced contract monitoring, and a restricted-access tender system. It highlighted a 0.4% estimated error rate in administrative expenditure, with 99.4% utilization of the CoR’s €90.8 million commitment appropriations (72% allocated to personnel, 28% to operational costs). The resolution urged strict budget restraint, financing new activities through savings, and praised the CoR’s four-stage budgetary process, EMAS certification (with a request for renewable energy usage data), and collaboration with the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC) to achieve savings via joint services. It called for timely internal audits, improved HR transparency (including training and nationality breakdowns), and online publication of members’ financial interests, reaffirmed by the CoR’s December 2011 decision. The Parliament commended the CoR’s role in subsidiarity and multi-level governance under the Europe 2020 strategy, endorsed its annual impact report as an evaluation tool, and requested all CoR opinions be attached to relevant legislative files.

title: Discharge 2010: EU general budget, Committee of the Regions - Motion for resolution: REPORT on the discharge for implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2010, Section VII – Committee of the Regions
background: In 2010, the European Court of Auditors identified procedural irregularities in the Committee of the Regions' staff recruitment and procurement, alongside its annual financial reports and internal audits. The Parliament will discuss compliance with budgetary regulations and financial management oversight for the Committee of the Regions' 2010 EU budget implementation.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the discharge approval, citing the unresolved 3.7% overall error rate which entirely againsts with EFD's demand for fiscal accountability and transparent EU spending.  
EFD opposes the CoR's administrative budget structure (72% personnel costs) as emblematic of bureaucratic excess, inconsistent with EFD's principles of efficient public fund utilization.  
EFD condemns the political nature of the discharge procedure highlighted by inconsistent scrutiny between institutions, opposing the issue's endorsement of flawed management practices.  
EFD entirely againsts with continued funding for CoR and EESC, noting their €200 million annual expenditure fails to deliver tangible European value as per EFD's anti-waste doctrine.  
EFD demands immediate budget reductions to Brussels institutions, aligning with their position that taxpayer funds should cease flowing to mismanaged EU bodies.

GREEN_EFA strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on transparency, particularly the Committee of the Regions’ publication of members’ financial interests online, which aligns with their core advocacy for institutional accountability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the harmonization of personnel rules between the CoR and EESC as a critical step toward ethical governance, echoing their manifesto priorities for standardized public sector integrity.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing conflict-of-interest safeguards for EU agencies, citing the debate’s concerns about EFSA and EMA, by mandating stricter cooling-off periods and banning ties to industry-funded groups like ILSI.  
GREEN_EFA approves the issue’s focus on renewable energy reporting under EMAS certification, urging expansion to all agencies to advance climate accountability frameworks.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the need for independent scientific research in agency evaluations, framing the debate’s criticism of industry-dominated data as an opportunity to amend procurement rules for balanced expertise.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue’s emphasis on transparency, particularly the Committee of the Regions’ publication of members’ financial interests online, which aligns perfectly with ALDE’s commitment to open governance and public accountability.  
ALDE commends the corrective measures implemented by the CoR, including enhanced procurement documentation and recruitment procedures, as these directly address the Court of Auditors’ findings while advancing ALDE’s priorities for efficient administrative reform.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical role of Member States in reducing error rates, urging stricter compliance with Article 44 of the interinstitutional agreement to ensure timely submission of national assurance statements, a point raised by Jan Mulder that reinforces ALDE’s focus on shared fiscal responsibility.  
ALDE welcomes the harmonization of personnel rules between the CoR and EESC as a step toward institutional efficiency but proposes extending this collaboration to include joint audits, reflecting Michael Theurer’s call for improved Council-Parliament cooperation in budgetary oversight.  
ALDE advocates integrating the European Development Fund into the EU budget framework, as highlighted by Olle Schmidt, to strengthen democratic scrutiny—a minor but strategic enhancement to the issue’s existing focus on accountability.

SD strongly sanctions the discharge approval while commending the Committee of Regions' implementation of corrective measures in recruitment and procurement, aligning with SD's emphasis on institutional accountability through improved documentation practices.  
SD approves the issue's balanced approach to error rate acknowledgment but proposes future discharge procedures prioritize proportionality in scrutiny to avoid excessive focus on agencies representing <0.5% of the EU budget.  
SD fundamentally agrees maintaining the European Institute for Gender Equality's independence, rejecting merger proposals as incompatible with SD's commitment to specialized gender mainstreaming tools under Europe 2020.  
SD strongly sanctions harmonizing personnel rules across EU bodies while advocating for enhanced conflict-of-interest frameworks that preserve agencies' ability to collaborate with technical experts without procedural delays.  
SD applauds the issue's emphasis on renewable energy reporting through EMAS certification as advancing SD's climate priorities, urging quarterly public updates on CoR's sustainability metrics.

ECR rejects the discharge approval as fully doubting with their principle that no EU institution should receive budgetary clearance while systemic management errors persist.  
The issue's acceptance of a 0.4% administrative error rate directly contradicts ECR's emphasis on structural fund mismanagement reaching "alarming" levels requiring immediate regime changes.  
ECR opposes the issue's endorsement of future CoR budget increases, citing its inconsistency with their demand to reduce operating costs through shared agency services and austerity alignment.  
The proposal fails to address ECR's core requirement for a full-time budgetary control commissioner, leaving oversight mechanisms inadequate to prevent recurring deficiencies.  
ECR condemns the issue's silence on Parliament's own unaccountable expense allowances (€4,300/month), which undermines its credibility to enforce transparency standards on other institutions.

GUE/NGL strongly agrees the discharge approval, commending the CoR’s enhanced transparency in publishing members’ financial interests online, which aligns perfectly with their commitment to democratic accountability and taxpayer oversight.  
GUE/NGL applauds the CoR’s corrective measures in procurement and recruitment, recognizing these as critical steps toward rigorous financial governance and trust-building with EU citizens.  
GUE/NGL proposes expanding the CoR’s EMAS environmental reporting to include granular data on renewable energy adoption, ensuring alignment with broader sustainability goals.  
GUE/NGL emphasizes the necessity of preserving specialized EU bodies’ mandates, as reflected in their opposition to merging EIGE, and praises the CoR’s subsidiarity role as a model for multi-level governance.  
GUE/NGL urges further harmonization of personnel rules between the CoR and EESC to maximize efficiency savings, while maintaining strict adherence to fair labor standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined actions regarding the Committee of the Regions’ (CoR) 2010 budget implementation, granting discharge while noting errors identified by the Court of Auditors in staff recruitment and procurement for interpreting services. It acknowledged corrective measures by the CoR, including improved recruitment procedures, enhanced procurement documentation, and a restricted-access tender monitoring system. The resolution highlighted a 0.4% estimated error rate in administrative expenditure, with 99.4% utilization of €90.8 million commitment appropriations (72% for personnel, 28% operational costs), urging future budget increases to be minimized and funded through savings. It welcomed the CoR’s four-stage budgetary procedure, EMAS certification in 2011 (requesting data on renewable energy use), and cooperation savings with the European Economic and Social Committee (EESC), while calling for further harmonization of personnel rules. The Parliament emphasized transparency, praising the CoR’s online publication of members’ financial interests, and recognized the CoR’s strengthened role in subsidiarity and multi-level governance under the Europe 2020 strategy. It requested timely internal audits, an exhaustive human resources breakdown in activity reports, and attachment of CoR opinions to relevant legislative files, commending the CoR’s annual impact report as a valuable accountability tool.

title: Discharge 2010: EU general budget, Council - Decision on the discharge: REPORT on the discharge for implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2010, Section II – Council
background: The 2010 EU budget discharge process for the Council followed the European Court of Auditors' report identifying issues including advance payments for the Residence Palace project and budgetary planning discrepancies. The Council's historical reluctance to engage in discharge procedures and institutional disagreements over financial accountability frameworks persisted. The Parliament will discuss granting discharge for the Council's 2010 budget implementation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the issue's emphasis on budgetary transparency and accountability, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to rigorous financial oversight and taxpayer trust in EU institutions.  
EPP proposes maintaining specialized agencies like the European Institute for Gender Equality as distinct entities to preserve their unique mandates, while endorsing broader systemic reforms to optimize resource efficiency across all EU bodies.  
EPP approves the insistence on completing internal audits and delivering the Court of Auditors' cost-benchmarking report, which directly advances the issue's goal of addressing incomplete documentation and strengthening oversight mechanisms.  
EPP applauds the focus on stricter procurement rules and conflict-of-interest safeguards for agencies, matching EPP's 2023 manifesto priorities to eliminate financial irregularities and ensure impartial expert assessments.  
EPP emphasizes the urgency of resolving interinstitutional cooperation gaps with the Council, strongly backing the issue's call for public dialogue to enforce compliance with budgetary accuracy principles under Article 319 of the EU Treaty.

EFD strongly promotes the issue’s focus on Council accountability, aligning perfectly with EFD’s longstanding commitment to rigorous scrutiny of EU budgetary mismanagement.  
EFD approves the condemnation of the Council’s refusal to engage in dialogue, as this reinforces EFD’s priority of transparency and taxpayer rights in EU fund oversight.  
EFD highlights the unresolved 2007-2009 discharge delays as a critical enhancement opportunity to strengthen interinstitutional compliance with financial regulations.  
EFD emphasizes the need to apply similar scrutiny to other EU bodies, proposing extending audit requirements to all agencies to match the rigor applied to the Council.  
EFD applauds the issue’s alignment with fiscal responsibility principles, particularly its challenge to the Residence Palace project’s budgetary breaches.

GREEN_EFA completely upholds the issue’s emphasis on Council transparency, perfectly aligning with their decades-long campaign for EU institutional accountability and taxpayers’ right to scrutinize public spending.

The resolution noted EFSA’s core mandate to provide independent scientific advice, risk assessments, and data analysis to inform EU food safety policies, with a 2010 budget of €74.7 million (up from €71.4 million in 2009). resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the European Railway Agency’s 2009 budget implementation, granting discharge to its Director while highlighting critical issues. While praising ECHA’s alignment with EU priorities and successful launch, Parliament called for enhanced planning, financial monitoring, customer engagement, and feedback mechanisms, acknowledging the Agency’s role in complementing Commission efforts under REACH.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the European GNSS Supervisory Authority’s 2008 financial management, granting discharge but highlighting issues flagged by the Court of Auditors, which qualified its assurance on the reliability of accounts and legality of transactions. It noted the Authority’s budget was drastically reduced from €436.5 million in 2007 to €22.7 million in 2008 following Regulation (EC) No 683/2008, which transferred responsibility for Galileo and EGNOS programs to the Commission. Despite this, the Commission transferred €95 million to the Authority in December 2008 without an amending budget, and the Authority’s accounts inaccurately listed €58.4 million as prefinancing (rather than a debt to the Commission) and €55.6 million as payable to the European Space Agency, which fell under the Commission’s responsibility. The Authority justified delayed asset transfers until July 2009 due to unresolved arrangements with the Commission. The resolution referenced the Court of Auditors’ Special Report No 7/2009 urging improved Commission management of Galileo and noted pending Internal Audit Service recommendations on sensitive posts and job descriptions. resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the rapid expansion of EU agencies, noting their number grew from 11 in 2000 to 29 in 2010, with budget allocations increasing by 610% (€94.7 million to €578.87 million) and staff numbers rising by 271% (1,219 to 4,794), while their share of the EU budget grew from 0.102% to 0.477%. It highlighted systemic weaknesses, including poor financial planning leading to excessive carryovers and budget execution delays, recurrent procurement deficiencies (e.g., lack of market value estimates and contract monitoring), and staffing challenges such as recruitment gaps and reliance on interim staff for sensitive roles. The resolution criticized inefficient governance structures, particularly in small agencies (e.g., European Police College with a 27-member board for 24 staff), and urged rationalization through mergers, shared support services, and common standards for host agreements to address logistical and social inclusion issues. It called for enhanced accountability via activity-based budgeting, performance metrics (SMART objectives, RACER indicators), and mandatory inclusion of annual operational comparisons in audit reports. The Parliament endorsed best practices like the European Food Safety Authority’s audit committee and risk assessment system, the Environment Agency’s real-time management tools, and the Foundation for Living and Working Conditions’ impact monitoring. It stressed the need for the interinstitutional working group on agencies to establish minimum standards, improve governance (e.g., Commission blocking minority votes on management boards), and define director qualifications, while urging the Commission to assist smaller agencies administratively and address cash management inefficiencies.

The Parliament acknowledged effective initiatives like the HELP anti-tobacco campaign (fully implemented in 2010) and the revamped Your Europe Portal, while demanding corrective measures for delays in health and education payments, stricter oversight of ESF funds (94% of €10.8 billion cohesion spending), and transparency in redirected projects like the pan-European TV network. It reiterated the need for systematic cost-benefit evaluations, risk monitoring, and SMART objectives in future programming to align with EU strategic interests and values.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over the 2010 EU budget’s implementation, noting the Court of Auditors’ finding that payments were free from material error but highlighted quantifiable eligibility errors in intermediate and final expenditure, alongside non-quantifiable risks in procurement and contract extensions, which remain vulnerable to fraud. It stressed the need for improved oversight in External Action/Development/Enlargement policies, where control systems were deemed partially effective, urging the Commission and EEAS to enhance payment regularity and rigorously monitor risks in budget support, including fraud and corruption. While acknowledging inherent risks in external aid, Parliament called for systematic cost/benefit evaluations of interventions, balanced with strategic EU interests, and emphasized donor coordination with Member States and international organizations. In cohesion policy, 18% of expenditure (€10.8 billion commitments, €7.1 billion payments via the European Social Fund) faced a 7.7% error rate, driven by procurement non-compliance; Member States were urged to improve fund management, with scrutiny of financial engineering instruments and support for the Globalisation Fund’s €105 million in projects. Environmental and climate actions achieved 99.26% execution (€240 million for LIFE+ grants), while public health saw 99.7% commitment execution but delays in payments. Parliament criticized customs and VAT evasion vulnerabilities, advocating simplified procurement rules and stronger consumer protection mechanisms, including SOLVIT and the European Consumer Centres. Regional policy disbursed €30.557 billion, with 49% of audited payments error-prone (mainly procurement and eligibility issues), urging simplification and stricter controls. Gender-responsive budgeting was lacking, and Parliament demanded audits assessing gender impacts. Lastly, it highlighted mismanagement in education/culture programs and the abrupt closure of a pan-European TV project without parliamentary consent, demanding transparency. Overall, the resolution underscored the need for enhanced accountability, error reduction, and strategic alignment with EU priorities.

stances.stance:
